div.p:
XXIII DennettPowell 167
We - entered at Sanshuré and another
at Sesheke - But the lands
both East and West of the
Barotse valley are free from
folio 155 the ^ insect plague - There however
the slave trade had defiled
the path and no one ought
to follow in its wake unless
well armed - The Mambari
had informed me too that
many English lived at
LoandoLuanda so I prepared to
go thither The prospect of
meeting with countrymen
seemed to overbalance the toils
of the longer march -

A "picho" ^ (calling) or assembly was
called to deliberate on the step
T In these great freedom of speech
is allowed, and on
this occasion one of the old
diviners said "Where is he
taking you to? This white
man is throwing you away -
Your garments smell
of blood already - " It is curious
to observe how identity of
character appears all over
the world - This man was
a noted crokaker - He always
dreamed something dreadful
in every expedition and was
certain an eclipse or comet
betokédbetokened the property of flight
1
168
but Sebituane always set his
visions down to cowardice and
Sekeletu only laughed at him
now - The general voice
was in my favour so a band
of ^ twenty seven Thirty were appointed
to accompany me to the West -
These men were not hired by
me but sent to enable me to
accomplish an object as much
desired by the chief and most
of his people as by me - They
were eager to obtain free
and profitable trade with
white men - The prices which
the Cape Me merchants could
give after defraying the
great expenses of such a
long journey being so very
small as to makde it
scarce worth while for the
natives to collect produce
for that market - And the
Mambari giving only a few
bits of red or print and baize
for elephantselephant's tusks with
more Pounds than they gave
yards of cloth, had produced
the belief that trade with
them was throwing ivory
away - Their desire of the
Makololo for direct trade
with the sea coast coincided
exactly with mine that no
2
169
permanent elevation of a people
can be effected without commerce
There could not either be a
permanent mission here
unless the missionaries should
descend to the level of the
natives Makololo for even
at Kolobeng we found that
traders demanded three or four
times the price of the articles
we needed and expected us
to be grateful besides for
letting us have the articles
besides at all -

The three men whom I had
brought from Kuruman had
frequent relapses of the fever
so finding that instead of
serving me I had to wait
on them I decided that they
should return to the South with
Fleming as soon as he had
finished his trading - I was then
entirely dependant on my
twenty seven ^ thirty men whom I
shall name Zambesians for
they were composed of two
Makololo only - and the rest Barotse
Batoka - Bashubia and two of
the Ambonda - These

The fever had caused
considerable weakness in my
own case and a strange giddiness
when I looked up suddenly
3
170
to any celestial object for everything
seemed to rush to the left and
if I did not catch hold of something
I fell heavily on the ground
something resembling a gush
of bile along the duct from
the liver caused the same fit
to occur at night on suddenly
turning round -

The Makololo put the
question "If In the event of your
death ^ would will the white people would
not blame themus for having
allowed meyou to go away into
an unhealthy unknown country"
of enemies?" ^ I replied that none of my friends
would blame them - because I
would leave a book with them
Sekeletu ^ to be sent to Mr Moffat in case
I did not return which would
explain to him all that had
occurred happened untilluntil the
time of my departure - The
book was a volume of my
Journal - and as I was
detained longer than MyI expected
at LoandoLuanda the book was with
a letter was delivered to a trader
and I have been unable to
trace it - I regret this now
as it contained valuable notes
on the habits of wild animals
and the request was made
in the letter to covey the
volume to my family
4
171
The prospect of passing away
from this fair and beautiful
world thus came before
me in pretty plain matter
of fact form, and it did
seem a serious thing to
leave wife & f children,
breaking up all connections
with earth and entering
on an untried state of
existence, and I find myself
in my journal wondering
over that fearful change
migration which lands
us in Eternity if an Angel
will soothe the fluttering
soul sadly flurried as
it must be on entering
the spirit world and hoping
that Jesus might speak
but one word of peace
for that would establish
in the bosom an ever-
lasting calm - But as I
had always believed
that if we serve God at all
it ought to be done in a
manly way - I wrote to
my brother commending
our little girl to his care
as I was determined to
"succeed or perish" in the
attempt to open this part
of Africa - The Boers
5
172
by taking possession of
all my goods had saved
me the trouble of making
a will and considering the
light heart now left in
my bosom and some
occasionalfaint efforts to perform
the duty of christianChristian forgiveness
I felt that it was better
to be the plundered than
one of the plunderers -

When I committed the waggons
and remaining goods to the care
of the Makololo - They took all
the articles except one box
into their huts - And two warriors
Ponuane & Mahale ^ brought froward each a
fine hieferheifer calf - After
performing a number of
warlike evolutions they asked
the chief to witness the agreement
made between them that
whoever of the two should
kill a Matabele warrior first
in defence of the waggon
should possess both
the calves
6

I had three muskets for
my people a rifle and double
barrelled smooth bore for myself
and having seen such a
great abundance of game
in my visit to the Leeba
I imagined that I could easily
supply the wants of my
party - Wishing also to avoid
the discourage-mentdiscouragement which would
naturally be felt on meeting
any obstacles if my companions
were obliged to carry heavy
loads I took only two cannisters
of biscs a few biscuits - tea
a few two or three pounds of tea &
sugar - and about twenty of
coffee which as the Arabs
find though used without
either milk or sugar is
a most refreshing beverage
after fatigue or exposure
to the Sun - We carried these
7
1734
one small tin cannisters about
fifteen inches square containing
spare shirting trowserstrousers & shoes
to be used when we reached
civilized life & other in a bag
which were expected to wear
out in the way - Another of
the same size for medicines
and a third for books my
stock being a Nautical Almanac
Thomson's Logarithm tables
and a Bible - A forthfourth box
contained a Magic Lantern
which we found of much
use - The sextant and
artificial horizon thermometer
and compasses were
carried apart - My ammunition
was distributed through the whole
luggage in portions so that
if an accident should
befall one portion we
st could still have others
to fall back upon As I
had always Our chief hopes for
food were upon that but in
case of failure I took about
20lbs of beads worth almost
forty shillings which still remained
of the stock I brought from
the Cape Town a small
gipseygipsy tent
just sufficient
to sleep in
A sheep skin
mantle (as blanket and a
horse rug as a bed As I had always
found that the art of successful
travel consisted in taking as
few "impedimenta" as possible
and not forgetting to carry onesmy
wits about ^ me him mythe outfit
8
175
was rather spare and intended
to be still more so when we
should come to leave the
canoes - Some would consider
it injudicious to adopt this
plan but I had a secret
conviction that if I did not
succeed it would not be
for lack of the "nick nacks"
consid advertized as indispensable
for travellers but from
want of "pluck" or because
a large array of baggage
excited the cupidity of
Sedg the tribes through whose country
we wished to pass -

The instruments I carried
though few were the best of their kind
A sextant made by the famed
makers Troughton and Sims of
Fleet Street - A chronometer watch
with a stop to the second's hand - an
admirable contrivance for enabling
a person to take the exact time of
observations - It was constructed
by Dent of the Strand (61) for the
Royal Geographical Society &
pronounced by Mr Maclear to
equal most chronometers in
performance - For both these
excellent instruments I have much
pleasure in recording my obligations
to my good friend Colonel Steele
and to Mr Maclear for much
of my ability to use them Besides these
I had a thermometer
by Dollond -
A compass
from the Cape Observatory
and a small
pocket one
in addition
And a good
small
telescope &
stand capable
of being screwed
into a
tree or -
9

11th of November 1853 Left the
town of Linyanti accompanied
by Sekeletu and his principal
men to embark on the Chobe
The chief came to the river in order
to see that all was right at
parting - We crossed five branches
of the Chobe before reaching
the main stream - This bifurcation
must be the reason why it
appeared so small to Mr OswelOswell
and myself in 1851 - When all
the departing branches re-enter
it is a large deep river
The spot of embarkation was
the identical island where we
met Sebituane first known
as the island of Maunku - one
of his wives - The chief lent
me his own canoe and
as it was broader than usual
one could turn about in it
with ease - The Chobe is
much infested by Hippopotami
and as particular certain
elderly males are expelled the
herd they become soured in
their tempers and so misanthropic
as to attack every canoe that
passes near them - The herd
is never dangerous except
when a canoe passes
into the midst when they are
asleep - To avoid this
it is generally
recommended
to travel by
day near the
bank and
by night in
the middle of
the stream
In all other casesAs a general rule
10
177
they flee the approach of man
The "solitaries" however frequent
certain localities well known
to the inhabitants on the inhabitants
banks and like the rogue
Elephants are extremely dangerous -
We came at this time to a
canoe which had been smashed
to pieces by a blow from
the hind foot of one such of
them - And I was informed
by my men that if the same
should happen to ours the
proper way was to dive
to the bottom of the river
and hold on there for a
few seconds forbecause the
hippopotamus after smbreaking
a canoe always looks
for the people on the surface
and if he sees none
there he soon moves off -
I have seen some frightful
gashes made on the legs
of the people who have had
the misfortune to be
attacked and unable to
dive - This theanimal uses his teeth as
an offensive weapon though
quite a herbivorous feeder -
One of these "batchelorsbachelors" that
lives near the confluences
actually came out of his lair
and putting his head down ran
11 after the men who were passing
with very considerable speed -

The part of the river called
Zabesa or Zabenza is spread
out like a little lake surrounded
on all sides by dense masses
of ^ tall reed - The river below that
is always 100 or 120 yards
broad, deep and never dries up
so farmuch as to be fordable -
At certain parts where the
partial absence of reeds enables
affords a view of the opposite
banks to be obtained the
Makololo have placed villages
of observation against their
enemies the Matebele - We
visited all these in succession
and found here, as every where
also in the Makololo country
orders had preceded us "that
INãka (the doctor) must not be allowed to
12 become hungry" -

179
The banks of the Chobe are
like those of the Zouga of
soft calcareous tufa
and the river has cut out
for itself a deep perpendicular
sided bed - Where the tu
banks are high, as at the
spot where the waggons
stood in 1851 they are
covered with magnificent
trees - the habitat of Tsetse
and the retreat of various
antelopes wild hogs, zebras,
buffaloes & Elephants

Among the trees may
be observed some species
159 of [the Ficus Indica - Light
green coloured acacias
The splendid Motsintsela - and
evergreen cypress shaped
Motsouri - The fruit of
the last named was ripe
and the villagers presented
many dishes of its beautiful
pink coloured plums
They are used chiefly to
13 form a pleasant acid drink
The Motsintsela is a very
lofty tree yielding the wood
of which good canoes
are made and fruit
nutritious and good but like
many wild fruits of this
country the fleshy parts are
180
require to be enlarged by cultivation
It is nearly all stone -

The course of the river
we found to be extremely
tortuous, so much so indeed
we went to all points of
the compass every dozen
miles - WSome of us walked
from a bend at the village
of Moremi to another nearly
due East of that point
in six hours while the
canoes going at more than
double our speed took
twelve to accomplish the
same distance - And though
the river is from 13 to 15
feet in depth at its lowest
ebb, and broad enough to
allow a steamer to ply upon
it the suddenesssuddenness of the
bendings would prevent
navigation - But should
the country ever become
civilized the Chobe would
be a convenient natural
14 canal - We spent 42½1/2 hours
paddling at the rate of 5 miles
an hour in coming from
Linyanti to the confluence
There we found a dyke of
porphoriticporphyritic trap lying accross
the Leeambye

181
Berry The porphoriticporphyritic trap contains
chrystalscrystals which the water
gradually dissolves and leaves
the rock with a worm eaten
appearance - It is curious
to observe that the water
flowing over certain rocks as
in this instance imbibes
an appreciable though
necessarily most minute
portion of the minerals they
contain - The water of
the Chobe up to this point
is of a dark mossy hue
but here it suddenly assumes
a lighter tint - And wheverwherever
this light colour shewsshows
a greater amount of mineral
there are not mosquitoes
enough to cause serious
annoyance to any except
persons of very irritable
temperaments

The large island called
Mparia stands at the confluence
This is composed of trap of
a younger age than the
15 deep stratum of tufa in
which the Chobe has found
its bed for at that point
where they come together
the tufa has been trans-
formed into Saccharoid
limestone

The actual point of confluence
of these two rivers the Chobe
and Leeambye is ill defined
on account of each dividing
into several branches as they
inosculate - but when the
whole body of water comes
into one bed it is a goodly
sight for one who has spent
years in the thirsty south
Standing on one bank even
the keen eye of the natives
cannot detect whether two
large islands a few miles
East of the junction are
main land or not - During a
flight In former
years the Bamang-wato men
with carrying Sekomi as a child
in his mother's
arms were inveigled were separated
from their women with
the present chief Sekomi
as a child in his mother's
arms and inveigled on
to one of these islands by
the Batoka Makalaka chief
of Mparia on pretence
of ferrying them accrross
16 the Leeambye - They were
left to perish after seeing
their wives taken prisoners
by these cruel lords of the
Leeambye and Sekomi owed
his life to the compassion
of even one of the Bayeiye
183
who pitying the young chieftain
enabled his mother to make
her escape by night

While at holding service
at Mparia I observed a disease
similar to one too common
among the civilized - but
which I never met with
elsewhere in the centreal ofparts of
this country - There had
evidently been extensive
caries of the cranial bones
and there were now other
evidence of the same disease
When sitting among them
afterwards I asked the patient
if that complaint had not
followed ^ another "Manasa" The
rest said "No no - " but he
maintained it had - It is
referred to here as the only
instance of in which a close
resemblance to one of the
common diseases of civili-
-zation was seen in the
country
17

184
Having left the Chobe we turned
round and began to ascend the
Leeambye and on the 19th NovrNovember
again reached the town of
Sesheke - It stands on the
North bank of the river and contains
a large population of Makalaka
under Moriantsane brother
in law of Sebituane - There are
parties of various tribes here assembled
under their respective head-
-men but a few Makololo
rule over all - Their sway
though essentially despotic
is considerably modified
by certain customs and laws
One of the Makalaka had
speared an ox belonging to one
of the Makololo and being
unable to extract the spear
was discovered as the per-
-petrator of the deed - His object
had been to get a share of
the meat as the Moriantsane
is known to be liberal with
any food that comes into
his hands - The culprit was
bound hand and foot &
placed in the sun to force
18 him to pay a fine but he
continued to deny the guilt -
His mother believing in
the innocencyinnocence of her son
now came forward with
185
her hoe in hand and threatening
to cut down any one who
should dare to interfere untied
the cords with which he
had been bound and took
him home - This open defiance
of authority was not resented
by Moriantsane but referred
to at ^ Linyanti to Sekeletu

A circumstance which happened
here when I was present
with Sekeletu shewsshows that a
simple mode of punishment
with which we are familiar
did not strike the Makololo
mind

A stranger having visited
Sesheke for the purpose of
pa barter was robbed by
one of the Makalaka of
most of his goods - The
thief when caught confessed
the theft and that he
19 had given the articles to a
person who had removed
to a distance - The Makololo
were much enraged at the
idea of their good name
being compromised by
this treatment of a stranger
186
and as their way of punishing
a crime which causes much
indignation is to throw the
criminal into the river they
were puzzled because
this would not restore
the lost property - The case
was referred to me and
I solved the difficulty by
paying for the loss and
myself and sentencing the
thief to work out an equal
equivalent with his hoe in
a garden - This system
was immediately introduced
and thieves are now
sentenced to raise an amount
of corn proportioned to their
offences -

Powell Among the Bakwains
a woman who stole from
the garden of another was
obliged to part with her
her own entirely - It became the
property of her whose field
was injured by the crime
When Sechele saw the
convicts criminals working on the
roads in the Cape Colony
he at once introduced
20 the system into his tribe and
refusing fines compelled the
offenders to make a proper
road up to his town -
187
There is no stated day of rest
in any part of this country
except the day after the appearance
of the new moon - but they
then refrain only from
going to their gardens - A
curious custom not to be
found among the Bechuanas
prevails among the Black
tribes beyond them - They
watch most eagerly for
the first glimpse of the
new moon and when
they percieveperceive the faint
outline after the sun has
sunk set far indeep in ^ the West
they utter a loud shout of
Kua! and vociferate prayers to
it - My men for instance called
out "Let our journey bewith the
white man be prosperous!
Let our enemies perish and the
children of Nakae become rich -
May he have plenty of flesh in
this journey &c.&c."

I gave many public
addresses to the people of Sesheke
under the outspread camel
thorn tree which serves as
a shade to the Kotla on the high bank of
the river - It was pleasant
21 to see the long strings of men
women and children coming
winding along from different
188
quarters of the town behind their
respective headmen - They often
amounted to between five and
six hundred souls and required
an exertion of voice which
brought back the complaint
for which I had got the
uvula excised at the Cape
They were always very attentive
and Moriantsane in order
as he thought to please me
on one occasion rose up
in the middle of the discourse
and hurled his staff at the
heads of some young fellows
whom he saw working
with a skin instead of
listening - They sometimes
put very sensible questions
on the subjects brought
before them - & At other times
At other times introduce the
most frivolous nonsense
immediately after hearing the
the most solemn things -
Some begin to pray in secret
22 to Jesus as soon as they
hear of the white man's God
with but little idea of what
they are about and are no
doubt heard
by Him who
like a Father
pitieth his
children - Others waking
by night see recollect what
has been said about the
Future world so clearly they next
day ^ tell what a fright they got by
it and resolve not to listen
189
to ourthe teaching again and others
keep to the
determination
not to believe as as in certain the villagers certain villagers
in the South who put
all their cocks to death
because they they crowed
the words "Tlang lo rapeleng"
"Come along to prayers"

The man On recovering
partially from a severe attack
of fever which corcleaved
to me from thenear the
passing the village of Moremi on the
Chobe till now, we prepared
for our departure up the
river by sending messages
before us to prepare
food - We took from
Sesheke fou
four ElephantsElephant's
tusks with
us belonging
to Sekeletu
as a means
of testing the
difference
of prices
between the
Portuguese
whom we
expected to
reach and
the white
traders from
the South N Moriantsane supplied
us well with honey ^ milk and
meal The rains were just
commencing in this part
but though showers sufficient
to lay the dust had fallen
they had no influence whatever
on the amount of water in
the river but never was
there less in any part than
three hundred yards of a deep
flowing river stream

Our progress up the
river was rather slow, this
was caused by waiting
opposite different villages
for supplies of food
23
190
We might have beedone with
much less than we got but
my Makololo man Pitsane
knew of the generous orders
of Sekeletu and was not
at all disposed to allow
them to remain a dead letter
The villages of the Banyeti
contributed large quantities of
Mosibe a bright red bean
yielded by a large tree - The
pulp enclosing the seed
which is not much thicker
than a red wafer is the
portion used and it requires
the addition ^ honey to render it at all
palateablepalatable

Ledy To these were added great
numbers of the fruit of which
yields a variety of Nux vomica
from which we derive
that virulent poison
strychnia - The pulp between
the nuts is the part used
and it is of a pleasant
juicy nature having a sweet
acidulous taste - If The
fruit itself resembles a
large yellow orange but
the rind is hard hard
and like the pips and bark
contains much of the deadly
24 poison - They shewshow their
noxious quantities by an
intensely bitter taste -
